slidelink.displaytext: Untitled Scene
What is Hemoglobinophathy?
Hemoglobinophathy & Leukopoiesis, W B C Differential, and Lymphocyte Function
Which condition is described as homozygous and autosomal dominant, defect on chromosome 11, form mostly hemoglobin other than A?
Red cells containing Hgb S are:
A patient suffering hypoxia, acidosis, dehydration fever or exposure to cold can develop which of these conditions?
Which of this condition develops into Chronic hemolytic anemia, Recurrent painful attacks, Bacterial infections, Deterioration of tissue and organ function and Shortened life expectancy ?

Characteristics of this condition is Chronic hemolytic process, hypercellular bone marrow, red blood cell have life span of 10-20 days, reticulocytosis, high bilirubin and cholelithiasis and Hct: 20%-25% low. Which condition is it?

When spleen loses ability to clear abnormalities which indicates an initial of splenomegaly, Howell-Jolly bodies present on smear, and splenic atrophy (sepsis and splenic sequestration) is happening, which of the condition below is your patient mostly suffering from?
Which one is not a complication of sickle cell due to occlusions?
Sickle cell anemia is a homozygous autosomal dominant defect in which chromosome?
Sickle cell anemia is a homozygous autosomal dominant defect in which chromosome?
Sickle cell anemia will present which laboratory results?
What is this test called and Which indicate positive for Hgb S, Sickle cell anemia?
Correct the White blood cell count. you counted 180 WBC and 80 nRBCs. What is your correct WBC?
A crisis smear can be seen in a sickle cell patient. Check the answer that most describe this crysis?
An elliptical (blunt) cell and a thin pointed cell are indicative that your red cells are sickling. Which of these cells can be reversible?
In case there is no hemoglobin electrophoresis, what is the method of choice for screening newborns in USA?

The substitution of lysine for glutamic acid at the sixth position on the beta chain –HbS α2β26Gluà-Lys Inherited homozygously Hemoglobin C 80% Hemoglobin F 1% to 20% Hemoglobin A2 2% to 4% Is indicative of which condition?

The presence of normochromic and normocytic red cell with high MCHC, with hgb F in 1 to 20 % and Hgb A2 in 2 to 4 %, crystal cells (bars of gold) in peripheral smear, marked increase in target cells, nRBCs, and schistocytes are indicative of which hemoglobinopathy?

A combination of hemoglobin S and C with a total hemoglobin function of 8-10 g/dl, slight reticulocytosis (compensation) and it is less severe than sickle cell anemia but still may experience crisis. Which condition is it?
In this blood smear we see Target cells, nRBCs, polychromasia, Howell-Jolly bodies Few sickled cells. 50% Hgb S and 50% Hgb C.

Virtually no Hgb A is present. Microcytic hypochromic red cell are seen along with nRBCs, Target cells,↑ R D W, retics Polychromasia, Sickle cells. The patient has a large spleen (splenomegaly) and two bands present on electrophoresis - one at HgbS 50% and one at Hgb A2. which condition is it?
Inherit Hgb heterozygously or homozygously. Below we have a Microcytic hypochromic picture with Target cells and polychromasia. Heterozygote inherit 70% Hgb A and 30% Hgb E. which condition is it?
On alkaline electrophoresis we see 60% Hemoglobin A and 40% Hemoglobin C. Blood smear we see 40% target cells.

Found in 0.4% African Americans Most individuals are asymptomatic Migrates to same location as hemoglobin C and must be distinguished Citrate electrophoresis at p H 6.4 will isolate this band for positive identification. which condition is it?

Found in 0.4% African Americans Most individuals are asymptomatic Migrates to same location as hemoglobin C and must be distinguished Citrate electrophoresis at p H 6.4 will isolate this band for positive identification. which condition is it?
Where does all leukocytes originate from?
Which cell stage has reached the last division stage?
Indented central nucleus (2 to 5 nucleoli) and thin chromatin strands. Moderate blue cytoplasm, usually without granules.
CD marker: CD 45 , 38 , 34 , 33 , 13 HLA-DR In flow cytometry is the identity of which cell?
Oval, round, or eccentric nucleus Light red-purple chromatin Cytoplasm: moderate blue color with fine to large blue-red azurophilic granules. We see 1 to 3 prominent nucleoli.
Red-purple, oval, indented, denser nucleusCytoplasm: dusty, fine and red-blue granules.
CD marker: C D 45, 33, 13, 15, 11b/11c In flow cytometry is the identity of which cell?
C D markers same as myelocyte: C D 45, 33, 13, 15, 11b/11c
CD marker: C D 45, 13, 15, 11b/11c
Chromatin: eccentric, usually bilobed Cytoplasm: large red-orange specific granules containing histamine with orange-pink cytoplasm Response to parasitic, allergic, and hypersensitive reactions
Which of these leukocytes contain both histamine and heparin. Respond in hypersensitive reaction?
Marker C D 33, 13, 14
What cell is this?
Where is the secondary location for lymphocytes?
What responsibilities Lymphatic system does not have?

This cell Derive from bone marrow stem cells activated by I L-1 and I L-6. It represents 10 to 20% of lymphocytes and mature cells secrete antibodies. Part of humoral immunity and mature in bone marrow.
This cell represents 60% to 80% lymphocytes Cell-mediated immunity (example, tumor suppression) Mature in thymus
what is the reference range for Lymphs in adults?
what is the reference range for Monocytes in adults?
what is the reference range for Bands in adults?
Generally we consider doing a manual diff in WBCs when they are greater than?
One of the most significant findings in neutropenia is when absolute neutrophil count is less than 2.0 multiplied by 10⁹/liter. When does this occur?
Increase of WBC’s In bloodstream is a sign of:
Bands and occasional metamyelocytes is an indicative of:
Exaggerated response to infections and inflammation with W B C: 20 to 50 multiplied by 10⁹/liter , Immature cells present but no blasts
Peripheral smear contains immature W B C’s, n R B C’s (young R B C’s), and platelet abnormalities.

Excessive amount and intensity in granulation Response to enhanced lysosome enzyme production Much more vivid blue-black coloration Clusters of toxic granules appear in neutrophils Sometimes as heavy as basophils
What toxic change is it?

Changes in segmented neutrophils Vacuoles appear in the cytoplasm Prolonged exposure to drugs such as sulfonamides Blood held in storage for long periods of time: pseudo-vacuolization Large vacuoles usually sign of serious infection and possible sepsis
What toxic change is it?

Cytoplasmic inclusion composed of ribosomal R N A Near the cytoplasmic membrane, 1 to 5 micrometers in size Rod-shaped pale, bluish-gray structure Seen in neutrophils, maybe in monocytes and bands
What toxic change is it?
Döhle Bodies is seen in all, except for:
Tick-borne diseases: Rickettsia-like bacteria with monocytes present or Rickettsia-like bacteria Anaplasma phagocytophilum resulting in Human granulocytic anaplasmosis. Which condition is it?

Symptoms of this condition is onset of high fever, chills, and headache, low W B C, ↑liver enzymes, thrombocytopenia Mulberry-like inclusions may be seen in bone marrow granulocytes or monocytes. Which is it?
Autosomal dominant Associated with: Thrombocytopenia Giant platelets (poorly granulated) Larger Döhle bodies found in cytoplasm of neutrophils Appears in monocytes and lymphocytes Abnormal bleeding

Rare genetic disorder Associated with: Coarse, dark granules in all cell line neutrophils, lymphocytes, monocytes, eosinophils, and basophils Granulation consists of lipid depositions in the cytoplasm Decreased mucopolysaccharide production
Most common (dominant trait) Associated with: 70% to 95% hyposegmentation In heterozygotes: nucleus is dumbbell shaped In homozygotes: nucleus is spherical, no lobes

Rare autosomal recessive disorder of neutrophilic granules Associated with: Defective fusion protein crucial to lysosomal secretion Giant purple-gray cytoplasmic granules ↓ W B C chemotaxis and bactericidal killing function
Which condition is it? Lymphs and monos may show a single red granule in the cytoplasm Abnormal bleeding time Develop recurring infections with Staphylococcus aureus

Which condition is it? Increased cell size, basophilia, and cytoplasm Normal for young children (1 to 4 years) Seen in E B V and C M V, hepatitis A, B, and C Most common disease showing variation seen in infectious mononucleosis Caused by Epstein-Barr virus, which infects B lymphocytes Found in body fluid, especially saliva

Which condition is it? Sore throat, fatigue, anorexia, fever, and headaches Diagnosis is made from rapid agglutination tests, E L I S A, or careful examination of smear Reactive lymphocytosis: 10% to 60% Reactive lymphocytes, scalloping red cells with abundant royal blue cytoplasm

Which condition is it? Endemic worldwide Isolated from respiratory secretions, urine, semen, and cervical secretions Some have mononucleosis-like syndrome Member of herpes family 40% to 90% of blood donors show anti-C M V titers Donor blood for premature infants must be C M V negative

Which condition is it? Lymphocytes are primarily involved in this disease Lymphocytes show reactive changes such as extremely basophilic cytoplasm or possibly clefting and vacuolization Normal ratio of C D 4 (helper) to C D 8 (suppressor) cells is 2:1, but reduction in C D 4 causes ratio to be reversed and leads to a decline in immune capabilities.

Which condition is it? Patients frequently die of opportunistic infections Pneumocystis jiroveci Mycobacterium avum Neoplasms such as Kaposi’s sarcoma See Pancytopenia Neutropenia Anemia Thrombocytopenia

In Lipid storage disease, this is an strategic metabolic enzyme that is missing or inactive - Single gene deletion.
Undigested metabolic products accumulate in cells, and integrity of cells in R E S is affected.
Which cells are affected?

Enzyme Deficiencies in Specific Lipid Storage Diseases
β-Glucocerebrosidase
This enzyme is related to which lipid disease?

The cell is large with rod-shaped inclusions
This enzyme is related to which lipid disease?

Cell is large Appears round Evenly sized lipid accumulations
This enzyme is related to which lipid disease?

Phenomenon when patient’s blood reacts with E D T A Causes platelets to form a ring around neutrophils Produces a falsely low platelet count Can only be corrected once the patient’s sample is collected in sodium citrate.
Draw from Hemoglobinophaty Leukopoiesis, W B C Differential, and Lymphocyte Function

Enzyme Deficiencies in Specific Lipid Storage Diseases
Sphingomyelinase
This enzyme is related to which lipid disease?

Neutrophils with greater than 5 lobes. Usually seen in megaloblastic processes Folic acid Pernicious anemia Vitamin B12 deficiency
Which is it?
Conditions that causes increased Neutrophils and Eosinophil. *Drag and drop
Conditions that causes increased WBCs *Drag and drop
